info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 15 at 12:48PM EST by NWS Chicago
info.description: ...Heavy Rainfall and Shifting River Ice Remain Likely... Warmer temperatures today into tomorrow will be followed by widespread rainfall Wednesday night into Thursday, some of which may be heavy in localized areas. Due to a combination of snow melt and rainfall, significant river rises are likely with water levels near flood stage possible. Conditions are also favorable for break-up ice jams, with this risk increasing by late week, especially on the Kankakee, Iroquois, and Vermilion Rivers, due to heavy ice cover currently in place. This flood potential exists from today through the weekend. Snow cover contains up to one inch of water equivalent, most of which will melt by Thursday morning, adding to runoff due to rainfall. Soil frost depths range from 6 to 12 inches across the outlook area, which may be enough to reduce infiltration from rainfall and snow melt. Soil moisture across the area is near average, which will not significantly impact flood risk. Overall, conditions are generally increasing the risk of flooding if heavy rainfall was to occur. River forecasts based upon 48 hours of future rainfall indicate significant river rises and near flood stage conditions at multiple locations in the outlook area, especially in the Iroquois and Kankakee river basins. Recent reports from river ice spotters and imagery from satellite indicate that heavy ice cover still exists in several areas. River rises from a combination of ongoing snow melt and future rainfall are likely to break up ice cover in some areas, which may lead to break-up ice jams. Ice jams can develop quickly and lead to rapid water level fluctuations with little or no notice. This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor the latest forecasts and statements, including possible flood watches and warnings. The next outlook update is expected by tomorrow morning.
